Hello everyone,

Just a reminder: Experienced programmer but very new to NEAT/neuroevolution.

I am having an issue with species (and population) stagnation in my latest 
experiment and so I have been looking at the speciation components of NEAT 
quite intently.  I have a couple of questions regarding the fitness penalty 
for species that have gone past the dropoff_age point with no improvement.

In the C++ version of NEAT that I downloaded, there doesn't seem to be any 
check to see if the species being penalized is one of the top (if not *the* 
top) performers.  The literature I've read on NEAT says "in order to prevent 
stagnation, the lowest performing species over N generations old [is] not 
allowed to reproduce".  I don't see any such checks for "lowest performing 
species".  This leads into my second question.

If this is in fact the case, that no checks are made, then surely the 
population stagnancy check would not do much good, no?  The idea here seems 
to be not to allow any species to reproduce except for the top two if the 
entire population has not improved best fitness over N+5 generations (C++ 
version again).  Surely, since the best species would have been sterile -5 
generations ago, at this point, only allowing it and the one below it to 
reproduce won't have much more of an effect than allowing any species to 
reproduce.

Obviously I am missing something here, but I don't seem to be able to put my 
finger on it.  Any help would be greatly appreciated.

Cheers,
Mike
